description: Whether participants receive uncertain information about a certain aspect of the game. This also includes receiving detailed vs less specific information, as well as events happening certainly versus events happening with a probability.

label: Replenishment rate
description: The replenishment rate in the resource dilemma. The remaining resource in the common pool is multiplied by the replenishment rate (â¥1) after each trial

label: High
description: The treatment was classified as having a relative high level of uncertainty

label: t
description: t statistic

label: Partner's gender is known
description: Whether participants were aware of the gender of their partner(s). TRUE = Participants were aware of the gender of their partner(s), FALSE = Participants were not aware of the gender of their partner(s).

label: Non-monetary Social
description: Participants receive social incentives, such as blame or praise, from others based on the outcomes of the game

label: Intergroup competition
description: A setting whereby multiple groups each experience a social dilemma, incentive structures can promote that groups compete for better outcomes (e.g., the group with better outcomes receives higher earnings), and/or group outcomes of the dilemmas are compared to each other (which can facilitate intergroup competition).

label: Individual group
description: Group of individuals making decisions that only affect that group

label: intergroup competition
description: Two groups and the higher earning group wins, or earns more

label: Return from public account
description: Payoff obtained from the tokens invested in the public account

label: Iterated pre-programmed cooperation rate
description: The pre-programmed cooperation rate of a partner (0.5 is 'random').

label: Iterated strategy
description: The specific strategy played by the participant's partner in an iterated game.

label: Preprogrammed Cooperation Rate
description: The partner cooperates randomly with a given cooperation rate across the duration of the game

label: Proportion of cooperation in the experimental condition
description: Proportion of cooperative choices in the experimental condition. Proportions are reported when the game (e.g., prisoner's dilemma or public goods dilemma) had a maximum number of two choice options. Higher numbers equal higher cooperation.

label: Tit-for-Tat
description: The partner cooperates on the first trial, then copies the previous choices of the focal participant on each subsequent trial

label: Emotion
description: Emotions are discrete, automatic responses to universally shared, culture-specific and individual-specific events (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011).

label: Fear
description: The response to the threat of harm (physical or psychological; Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

label: Emotion manipulation
description: Whether emotions of participants were elicited experimentally or measured through some instruments (e.g., questionnaires). TRUE = Participant's emotions were experimentally manipulated, FALSE = Participant's emotions were measured.

label: Happiness
description: Feelings that are enjoyed, that are sought by the person (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

label: Negative emotion
description: Leader expressed negativity

label: Positive emotion
description: Leader expressed positivity

label: Feedback content
description: What type of feedback information participants receive after each trial of the game (Note that earnings feedback might entails other feedback contents, such as feedback about rank).

label: Choice
description: Feedback about contributions, withdrawals, or binary decisions

label: Feedback target
description: What type of information participants received about their partner(s) decisions and/or outcomes after each trial of the game (Note that Individual feedback entails Group feedback).

label: Individual
description: Feedback about each group memberâs behavior is provided

label: Group
description: Feedback about the groupâs aggregate behavior (e.g., mean contribution, sum of contributions)

label: Individualism
description: Individualists will see themselves as more differentiated and separate from others, and place more importance on asserting their individuality (Bochner, 1994, p. 274)

label: Individual difference level
description: Agents were classified according to a specific individual difference measure that could be measured (e.g., via a questionnaire) or manipulated (elicited experimentally). Each study might have its own grouping criterion (e.g., via a median split).

label: High
description: Participants were classified as high according to the specific individual difference

label: Low
description: Participants were classified as low according to the specific individual difference

label: Absent
description: No feedback is provided

label: Participant's behavior level
description: Whether participants or groups are classified or grouped according to their cooperative behavior (cooperative/high contributions vs competitive/low contributions) in early stage of the games or in other games.

label: Low
description: participants or groups are classified as displaying a low cooperative behavior

label: High
description: participants or groups are classified as displaying a high cooperative behavior

label: Partner's behavior level
description: Whether other players are classified or grouped according to their cooperative behavior (cooperative/high contributions vs competitive/low contributions) in early stage of the games or in other games.

label: High
description: Other players are classified as displaying a high cooperative behavior

label: Low
description: Other players are classified as displaying a low cooperative behavior

label: Identification level
description: Extent to which the participants identify with their partner(s).

label: Low
description: Participant's identification with their partner is low

label: High
description: Participant's identification with their partner is high

label: Anonymity manipulation
description: Degree to which participants' actions were identifiable by their partner(s) and/or the experimenter.

label: High
description: The treatment was classified as having a relative high level of anonymity

label: Block
description: Data were analyzed at the block level, so that cooperation for each block is used as observation in the analysis

label: Low
description: The treatment was classified as having a relative low level of anonymity

label: Other
description: Feedback about behavior of other specific participants in the game that do not fall under any of the Feedback target categories (e.g., only feedback from a few individuals is provided)

label: Trust propensity
description: A personâs general willingness to trust others (Mayer, Davis, & Schoorman, 1995, p. 714) [based on] expectation of partnerâs goodwill and benign intent (Yamagishi & Yamagishi, 1994, p. 131)

label: W
description: Wilcoxon signed-rank test

label: Peer
description: Other participants of the same role

label: Punishment effectiveness
description: The ratio of the cost of punishment for the participant who decides to punish, to the cost of punishment for the participant who receives the punishment (e.g., if punishment costs 1 point to inflict a cost of 3 points, = .33).

label: Monetary
description: An amount of money often converted from game points

label: Preference for conditional cooperation
description: Participants are classified as having a specific dispositional strategy of cooperation using a strategy method (see Fischbacher et al. 2001).

label: Freeriders
description: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants who always contributed nothing to the public good

label: Conditional cooperators
description: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants who had an increasing amount of contributions or had a significant positive slope of own contribution with average group contribution

label: Hump-shaped contributors
description: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants who initially provide increasing amounts to the public good according to increasing average group contributions, but then at some point give a significantly decreasing amount to the public good

label: Others
description: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants unable to be classified as (un)conditional cooperators, free riders or hump shaped contributors

label: Endogenous position
description: Whether the position in the sequence is exogenous (i.e., predetermined) or endogenous (i.e., based on players' decisions). Endogenous could also be choosing that the game is sequential and/or choosing position in the game. TRUE = Endogenous, FALSE = Exogenous.

label: Position in game
description: The positional order of the participant in the sequence of decisions (in a sequential game).

label: Sequentiality
description: Whether group members make their decisions simultaneously or sequentially, i.e., whether participants take decisions one after another while receiving some form of feedback about preceding decisions.

label: Sequential turn-taking
description: Participants make decisions one after another following some (endogenous or exogenous) order

label: Simultaneous
description: Participants make decisions simultaneously

label: Conflict index
description: Index that quantifies the degree of conflicting interests in the game.

label: K index
description: For 2-persons PDG, it is calculated as (R-P)/(T-S), and 0 < K < 1.

label: Conflict level
description: Relative level of the conflict of interests in the game.

label: High
description: High relative level of the conflict of interests in the game

label: Conflict index value
description: Numeric value of the specific conflict index.

label: Medium
description: Medium relative level of the conflict of interests in the game

label: Low
description: Low relative level of the conflict of interests in the game

label: Heterogeneous gender
description: Whether groups had a mixed gender composition (both males and women). TRUE = Groups had a mixed gender composition (both males and women), FALSE = Groups had a homogeneous gender composition (only males or only women).

label: Relationship with the partner
description: The type of relationship between the participant and their partner.

label: friend
description: Their partner is a friend

label: stranger
description: Their partner is a stranger

label: Predominantly Competitive
description: Partner competes over most trials, but the study doesn't specify the exact rate

label: Predominantly Cooperative
description: Partner cooperates over most trials, but the study doesn't specify the exact rate

label: Altruist
description: Altruists are more concerned with a positive outcome for others than for themselves (Bogaert, Boone, & Declerck, 2008)

label: Competitor
description: Competitors aim to maximize the relative difference between their own and the othersâ outcome

label: MPCR
description: The ratio of benefits to costs for a member to contribute one monetary unit to the group account. Calculated as multiplier divided by group size.

label: MPCR level
description: Relative level of the ratio of benefits to costs for a member to contribute one monetary unit to the group account.

label: Low
description: Low relative level of the ratio of benefits to costs for a member to contribute one monetary unit to the group account

label: Symmetric MPCR
description: Whether all participants within a group receive the same or different MPCR. TRUE = All participants within a group receive the same MPCR, FALSE = All participants within a group receive a different MPCR.

label: High
description: High relative level of the ratio of benefits to costs for a member to contribute one monetary unit to the group account

label: Self-presentation
description: The extent to which individuals can and do monitor their self-presentation, expressive behavior, and non-verbal affective display (Snyder, 1974, pp. 526/527), [potentially motivated by] the identity concern of oneâs [â¦] evaluation (De Cremer & Tyler, 2005, p. 121)

label: Give-Take frame
description: Give-some vs. take-some games are a form of valence framing involving changes in the suggested property rights. For instance, common pool games can be described as decisions on how much to âgiveâ to a public good (public goods games) or how much to âtakeâ from a collectively shared resource (commons dilemmas) (Gerlach, Jaeger, & Hertwig, 2018).

label: Give-some
description: The game is framed as a give-some dilemma, i.e., endowments are allocated to the player and can be contributed to the public good.

label: Take-some
description: The game is framed as a take-some dilemma, i.e., endowment is allocated to the public good (or common resource) and can be extracted by the player.

label: Academic discipline
description: Participant's field of study if the participant is a student.

label: Others
description: Participants were students of other disciplines than economics, psychology, or sociology

label: Student sample
description: Whether participants were recruited from a student population. TRUE = Participants were recruited from a student population, FALSE = Participants were not recruited from a student population.

label: Hypothetical
description: Hypothetical value for participants (e.g., points)

label: Trial of cooperation (ordinal)
description: Trial on which cooperation is assessed on an ordinal scale.

label: first
description: Cooperation assessed in the first trial

label: last
description: Cooperation assessed in the last trial

label: Assigned endowment
description: Whether the endowment is exogenously assigned at the beginning of the game. TRUE = The endowment is assigned exogenously at the beginning of the game, FALSE = The endowment is not assigned at the beginning of the game. It can be determined based on performance on a prior task (e.g., earned), or based on other mechanisms.

label: Endowment level
description: Relative level of tokens participants were endowed with in a Public Goods Game. Each study can have its own criterion for grouping the endowments into levels.

label: Low
description: Low relative level of tokens participants were endowed with in the game

label: High
description: High relative level of tokens participants were endowed with in the game

label: H
description: Kruskal-Wallis H statistic

label: Others
description: Feedback about other payoff-relevant information not mentioned in any of the Feedback content categories

label: Self-efficacy
description: People's beliefs in their ability to influence events that affect their lives (Bandura, 2010)

label: Contribution-based
description: Players who made a contribution less (or more) than a specified amount are punished

label: Outcome-based
description: Some set of players is punished if a collective threshold is (not) reached

label: Partner type
description: The type of partner that interacts with the participant in the game.

label: Stranger
description: General others outside the game (in formulations such as 'most people'; 'others in general'...)

label: Computer
description: Computerized opponent. Players must be informed to be interacting with a computer

label: Decision time (correlation)
description: Correlation between cooperation and time participants spend to make the decision.

label: Time pressure
description: Whether participants were instructed to make their decisions in a limited amount of time or with a longer amount of time.

label: time pressure
description: Participants are given a limited amount of time and asked to make their decision as quickly as possible

label: time delay
description: Participants are given relatively more time to think carefully about their decision before making it

label: Gain-Loss frame
description: Gain vs. loss framing is a form of valence framing (Levin, Schneider, & Gaeth, 1998; Gerlach, Jaeger, & Hertwig, 2018). Specifically, outcomes of the decision are either in the domain of gains (i.e., positively-valued) or in the domain of losses (i.e., negatively valued).

label: Gain
description: The game is framed in terms of gains, i.e., outcomes of decisions are positively-valued.

label: Loss
description: The game is framed in terms of losses, i.e., outcomes of decisions are negatively-valued. This includes games in which only some outcomes are negatively valued.

label: Iterated pre-programmed cooperation rate level
description: Relative level of the pre-programmed cooperation rate of a partner.

label: High
description: High relative level of the pre-programmed cooperation rate of a partner

label: Low
description: Low relative level of the pre-programmed cooperation rate of a partner

label: Primed construct
description: Participants were primed with a specific construct.

label: Other
description: Other primes

label: Neutral
description: No prime or a neutral prime

label: Sadness
description: The response to the loss of an object or person to which a person is very attached (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

label: Neutral
description: Often used as a baseline in studies that elicit emotions. Participants are exposed either to stimuli with neutral emotional valence or engage in a non-emotional control task

label: Group type
description: Whether the group the participant is interacting with is a naturally occurring group or experimentally induced group (e.g., minimal group paradigm).

label: Experimentally induced group
description: An experimentally induced group (e.g., minimal group paradigm)

label: Knowledge of group membership
description: Who has knowledge of the focal and target agents' group membership.

label: Common
description: The participant and their partner know each others' group membership

label: beta
description: standardized regression coefficient (beta)

label: Partner's group membership
description: Whether the participant is interacting with a partner identified as ingroup, outgroup, or stranger.

label: Ingroup
description: Partner(s) is a member of the participant's group

label: Outgroup
description: Partner(s) is a member of a different group than the participant

label: Other
description: Other uncertainty target not included in the existing categories

label: Lottery reward incentive
description: Whether there was a chance of lottery for a reward to occur (see lottery incentive). TRUE = A lottery was implemented for reward to occur, FALSE = A lottery was not implemented for reward to occur.

label: Reward agent
description: Who can enact reward on other participants (See Agent type).

label: Institution
description: Institutional mechanism inside (e.g., impersonal sanctioning system) or outside (e.g., public institutions like government)

label: Reward incentive
description: The form in which participants' reward decisions affect their partner's payoffs (see game incentive).

label: Hypothetical
description: Hypothetical value for participants (e.g., points)

label: Reward iterations
description: The number of iterations of reward per reward phase.

label: Reward probability
description: The probability that a reward decision is played out (and thus becomes beneficial to the rewarded agent).

label: Outcome-based
description: Some set of players are rewarded if a collective threshold is (not) reached

label: Sequential reward
description: Whether group members make their reward decisions simultaneously or sequentially, i.e., whether players take decisions one after another while receiving some form of feedback on preceding decisions (see Sequentiality).

label: Simultaneous
description: Participants make the reward decision at the same time (i.e., without receiving information about others' reward decisions)

label: Reward treatment
description: Reward is the imposition of positive payoffs on a specific player after a trial of the game.
The reward treatment

label: Rank-based
description: The n lowest- (or highest-) ranked participants are rewarded

label: Third Party
description: A person who does not interact with the participants in the main game e.g., a third-party punisher

label: Third Party
description: A person who does not interact with the participants in the main game e.g., a third-party punisher

label: Non-monetary Social
description: Participants receive social incentives, such as blame or praise, from others based on the outcomes of the game

label: Contribution-based
description: Participants who made a contribution less (or more) than a specified amount are rewarded

The baseline treatment. This is the treatment compared against any treatment coded as reward treatment (= 1 identifies the reward effect). This means that the treatment is equal to the reward treatment, except for the availability of reward (which includes other concepts that are part of reward, such as reward effectiveness, etc.)

label: Cognitive ability
description: One's general mental capability involving reasoning, problem solving, planning, abstract thinking, complex idea comprehension, and learning from experience (Gottfredson, 1997)

label: Group
description: Data were analyzed at the group level, so that cooperation displayed by each group as a whole is used as observation in the analysis
Is not a punishment treatment. This is any treatment that is neither a punishment treatment nor a baseline relative to the punishment treatment (In practice, these are ignored in the platform)
Is not a reward treatment. This is any treatment that is neither a punishment treatment nor a baseline relative to the punishment treatment (In practice, these are ignored in the platform)

label: Cognitive load treatment
description: Participants are exposed to a treatment aimed at increasing their cognitive load before the game (e.g., the Stroop Task). TRUE = cognitive load treatment, FALSE = Participants are not exposed to the cognitive load manipulation or are exposed to a filler control task that should not affect their cognitive load or should affect it less (e.g., a Stroop Task that requires less cognitive resources)

label: Decision maker
description: Participant(s) accountable for making a decision in the game. Mostly manipulated in studies examining interindividual-intergroup discontinuity.

label: individual
description: The decision maker is a single individual. Individuals make a single decision, to be then matched with others in the game, producing an outcome for all participants involved (e.g., each person making a decision in a 4-persons PGD)

label: Size of unit of decision maker
description: Number of participants constituting a single decision maker unit (e.g., if a 6-person public good is divided into 2 triads that each make decisions, then the decision maker unit size is 3; in a 6-person public good where each person makes their own decision, then the individual decision maker unit is 1).

label: Group size
description: Overall number of people affected by the choices in the game.

label: Group size level
description: Relative size of the group, in case exact group size is not provided or it is not relevant (e.g., different group sizes are collapsed together and compared with others).

label: Low
description: Small relative size of the group

label: Number of decision makers
description: Number of decision makers that each produce unique decisions that are used to calculate the collective payoff (e.g., 4 decision makers in a standard 4-persons PGD; 2 decision makers in a PDG with a 4-person group involving two subgroups that produce one decision each).

label: Medium
description: Medium relative size of the group

label: High
description: Large relative size of the group

label: Natural group
description: A naturally occurring group (e.g., political partisans, nationalities)

label: Stranger
description: Participants are not informed about whether their partner is an ingroup or outgroup member

label: Expectations level
description: Participant expectations have been manipulated in the study, or authors split the sample in some way based on stated expectations of partner cooperation.

label: Low
description: Participants have low expectations about the other player(s)' behavior in the game

label: High
description: Participants have medium expectations about the other player(s)' behavior in the game

label: Medium
description: Participants have medium expectations about the other player(s)' behavior in the game

label: M-X
description: McNemar test Chi-square statistic

label: Age
description: Participants' age, usually measured as self-reported participants' person years.

label: Economics
description: Participants were economics students

label: Academic grade level
description: Participants were grouped in different categories based on their academic grade. Each study can use its own criterion to make this classification.

label: Junior
description: Participants were classified as junior with respect to their academic grade

label: Senior
description: Participants were classified as senior with respect to their academic grade

label: Religiosity operationalization
description: How is the specific construct pertaining to the religious sphere operationalized in the study.

label: Religious setting
description: Participants interacted in a religious setting (e.g., church)

label: Religious exposure level
description: Whether participants were exposed to a high versus low level of religious content (e.g., enrolled to a religious vs non-religious school).

label: High
description: Participants were classified as having a relative high religious exposure

label: U
description: Mann-Whitney U statistic

label: Low
description: Participants were classified as having a relative low religious exposure

label: Religious affiliation
description: Participants reported to be affiliated to a specific religion

label: Religion
description: A prime that relates to religion

label: X
description: Chi-square statistic

label: Experimental setting
description: The setting in which the experiment was conducted.

label: Lab in the field
description: The experiment had all the characteristics of a lab experiment but it is carried out at a field site

label: Lab
description: The experiment was conducted in a laboratory (Classrooms used as laboratory setting are considered as lab)

label: Gossip
description: People were allowed to share evaluations to others about their partners behavior.

label: Absent
description: Gossip was absent in the study

label: Knowledge of partner's prior behavior
description: Participants were provided information about how their partner behaved previously in the current game or had behaved with others in a previous game (another closely related coding is feedback).

label: absent
description: Participants were not provided information about how their partner behaved in the current game or had behaved with others in a previous game

label: Present
description: Gossip was present in the study

label: present
description: Participants were provided information about how their partner behaved in the current game or had behaved with others in a previous game

label: Partner choice
description: Matching of participants based on either the players' or the experimenter's decision.

label: Migration
description: Players can choose to enter different groups (but not specific players, as all players can migrate)

label: Partner selection
description: Participants can be chosen for interactions based on past behavior.

label: absent
description: Participants can not be chosen for interactions based on past behavior

label: present
description: Participants can be chosen for interactions based on past behavior

label: Other
description: None of the conflict index categories apply

label: Intentions
description: Correlation between cooperation and intentions participants are requested to state before making a decision in the game.

label: Context frame
description: Context framing involves differently worded, but logically equivalent, descriptions of otherwise unchanged games (Gerlach, Jaeger, & Hertwig, 2018).

label: Cooperative
description: Cooperative frames refer to the participants' common interests

label: Motivational orientation
description: Participants were instructed to adopt a specific goal when interacting in the game.

label: Cooperative
description: Cooperative goals aim to equalize and/or maximize joint outcomes

label: Competitive
description: Competitive frames refer to discord and rivalry among the participants

label: Competitive
description: Competitive goals aim to maximize the relative difference between own and the othersâ outcome

label: Focal point frame
description: In coordination games, frames can used techniques to refer participants to a unique but principally arbitrary move by highlighting one particular choice (e.g., by bolding the text in one cell). TRUE = Has a focal point frame, FALSE = Has no focal point frame.

label: Generic
description: Generic frames refer to concepts other than moral, competitive, or cooperative

label: Normative beliefs
description: Correlation between cooperation and participants' beliefs about what others expect them to do.

label: Right-wing authoritatianism
description: Opposing any change in the social status quo, [â¦] favouring tough punishment of deviance, nonconformity, or innovation, [and] favouring traditional, old-fashioned lifestyles, behavioural norms, and values (Duckitt, Bizumic, Krauss, & Heled, 2010, p. 691)

label: Earnings
description: Feedback about earnings (included ranks based on earnings and performance)

label: Noise
description: Whether there is a mismatch (either positive or negative) between participants intended behavior and actual behavior communicated to one's partner. TRUE = Presence of a mismatch (either positive or negative) between participants intended behavior and actual behavior communicated to one's partner, FALSE = Absence of a mismatch (either positive or negative) between participants intended behavior and actual behavior communicated to one's partner.

label: Individualistic
description: Individualistic goals aim to maximize own outcomes, regardless of the othersâ outcomes

label: Ostracism
description: Participants could be avoided or rejected from a group. TRUE = Potential for ostracism was present, FALSE = Potential for ostracism was absent.

label: Medium
description: The treatment was classified as having a relative medium level of anonymity

label: Agreeableness (FFM)
description: [Individual] differences in the motivation to cooperate (vs. acting selfishly) in resource conflicts (Denissen & Penke, 2008, p. 1285)

label: Conscientiousness
description: The proactive side of Conscientiousness is seen most clearly in the need for achievement and commitment to work; the inhibitive side is seen in moral scrupulousness and cautiousness (Costa et al., 1991, p. 889)

label: Extraversion
description: [Individual differences in] engagement in social endeavors (such as socializing, leading, or entertaining) (Ashton & Lee, 2007, p. 156)

label: Neuroticism
description: A broad domain of negative affect, including predispositions to experience anxiety, anger, depression, shame, and other distressing emotions (Costa, Terracciano, & McCrae, 2001, p. 322)

label: Openness to experience
description: [Individual differences in] engagement in idea-related endeavors (such as learning, imagining, and thinking) (Ashton & Lee, 2007, p. 156)

label: Self-control
description: The ability to override or change oneâs inner responses, as well as to interrupt undesired behavioral tendencies (such as impulses) and refrain from acting on them (Tangney, Baumeister, & Boone, 2004, p. 274)

label: Risk-taking
description: Oneâs general degree of comfort with facing uncertain gains or losses (Ehrlich & Maestas, 2010, p. 658)

label: Positive affect
description: Individual differences in the tendency to experience positive emotions and feeling states (Stanton & Watson, 2014, p. 556)

label: Negative affect
description: Individual differences in the tendency to experience negative moods and feelings, including sadness, worry, and anger (Stanton & Watson, 2014, p. 556)

label: Medium
description: Medium relative level of tokens participants were endowed with in the game

label: Threshold
description: The minimum threshold of total contribution by all group members when the public good will be provided. This also defines the criticality of contributions, as contributions are more critical if other players cannot reach the threshold on their own (esp. in sequential games where othersâ prior contributions are known).

label: Threshold level
description: Relative level of the minimum threshold of total contribution by all group members when the public good will be provided. This also defines the criticality of contributions, as contributions are more critical if other players cannot reach the threshold on their own (esp. in sequential games where othersâ prior contributions are known).

label: Medium
description: Medium relative level of the minimum threshold of total contribution by all group members when the public good will be provided

label: High
description: High relative level of the minimum threshold of total contribution by all group members when the public good will be provided

label: Low
description: Low relative level of the minimum threshold of total contribution by all group members when the public good will be provided

label: Communication treatment
description: Whether communication was allowed between participants in the game. TRUE = Participants could communicate in the game, FALSE = Participants could not communicate in the game.

label: Communication content
description: What was the content of communication, either given by pre-specified messages or coded from free communication.

label: Request
description: Requests and suggestions (e.g., to cooperate or contribute)

label: Communication occurrence
description: Whether, in an iterated game, agents could communicate only once or throughout the experiment, such as before every trial.

label: One-shot
description: Participants could only communicate once, before the first trial of the game

label: Communication type
description: The mode of communication between participants in the game.

label: Written
description: Participants could communicate via written messages (either using free text entry or pre-written messages)

label: Restricted communication
description: Whether communication is restricted to pre-specified messages, or participants are free to formulate their own messages. TRUE = Communication restricted to pre-specified messages, FALSE = Free communication.

label: Block of cooperation (ordinal)
description: Block on which cooperation is assessed on an ordinal scale. Blocks are defined as chunks of trials aggregated together. Trials can be grouped in a block based on some manipulation in the game, but can also be aggregated based on arbitrary reasons not related to the study design (e.g., statistical analyses).

label: first
description: Cooperation assessed in the first block

label: last
description: Cooperation assessed in the last block

label: Real Partner
description: No experimental strategy is used and participants are playing according to actual game choices

label: Known endgame
description: Whether participants know the exact number of trials at the beginning of the experiment. Endgame is considered known also when participants played a one-shot game. TRUE = Known endgame, FALSE = Endgame not known.

label: Competition
description: A prime that may increase non-cooperation; such as conflict, business or economic context

label: Cooperation
description: A prime that may increase cooperation; includes primes about the concept of cooperation, community, interdependence, shared identity

label: Game incentive
description: Whether participantsâ decisions in the game determine their payoffs in different forms.

label: Monetary
description: Decisions in the game resulted in monetary outcomes, often converted from game points

label: Hypothetical
description: Decisions in the game resulted in outcomes with hypothetical value for participants (e.g., points)

label: Success
description: Feedback about the success of the group in reaching some payoff-relevant threshold in the game

label: Failure
description: Feedback about the failure of the group in reaching some payoff-relevant threshold in the game

label: Endogenous threshold
description: Whether the threshold is endogenously determined (e.g., through voting by participants). TRUE = Endogenous threshold, FALSE = Exogenous threshold.

label: Threshold
description: The minimum threshold of total contribution by all group members for the public good to be provided or the occurrence of a loss (e.g., in case of public bad games)

label: Resource size
description: Overall size of the resource that participants can withdraw in a resource dilemma game.

label: Resource size level
description: Relative size of the resource that participants can withdraw in a resource dilemma game.

label: Low
description: Low relative size of the resource that participants can withdraw in a resource dilemma game

label: High
description: High relative size of the resource that participants can withdraw in a resource dilemma game

label: Descriptive norm
description: Participants are provided information about how others typically behave in the game.

label: No Information
description: Participants are not provided information about how others have previously behaved in the game

label: Low Cooperation
description: Participants are told that people often displayed relatively low cooperation

label: Medium Cooperation
description: Participants are told that people often displayed relatively medium amounts of cooperation

label: High Cooperation
description: Participants are told that people often displayed relatively high amounts of cooperation

label: Optional communication
description: Whether participants had a choice to communicate (or not) with their partner. TRUE = Optional communication, FALSE = Mandatory communication.

label: Real communication
description: Whether the communication received by participants was real or fake. TRUE = Real communication, FALSE = Fake communication.

label: Verbal
description: Participate could speak to each other, either in person or via phone/voice chat

label: Other
description: Other content of messages

label: Random Appointment
description: Leader is randomly appointed

label: Lottery incentive
description: Whether the study involved a lottery to get paid (monetary or non-monetary) resources based on the outcome of the game. TRUE = A lottery was implemented as incentive, FALSE = A lottery was not implemented as incentive.

label: Show-up fee
description: Whether participants received a show-up fee for the study (i.e., a certain payment for participation). TRUE = Show-up fee, FALSE = No show-up fee.

label: Public Good-Bad frame
description: Public goods vs. public bads refer to the framing of the consequence of decisions for others. In public goods provision, contributions to the public good are described to provide a benefit to others. In public bad-type games, contributions to the public bad impose a cost on others, or contributions to the private good impose a negative externality on others.

label: Public Bad
description: The game is framed in terms of negative outcomes to others arising from contributions to the public bad or in terms of negative externalities from contributions to the private good.

label: Public Good
description: The game is framed in terms of positive outcomes to others arising from contributions to the public good.

label: Small-scale society
description: Participant's small-scale society of origin, according to the d-place classification. "Other" if small-scale society is not included in the d-society classification . A society can be understood to represent a group of people at a focal location with a shared language that differs from that of their neighbors" (Kirby et al., 2016).

label: Religious attendance
description: Participants reported the frequency of attending religious services (e.g., going to church)

label: Medium
description: Participants were classified as having a relative medium religious exposure

label: Trial
description: Data were analyzed at the trial level, so that cooperation for each trial is used as observation in the analysis

label: Number of blocks
description: The total number of blocks across the full experimental session. A block is a unit within the experiment in which trials have the same treatment and matching procedure. E.g., ten trials of partner-matched play followed by ten trials of partner-matched play with a different partner are two blocks of ten trials (because re-matching takes place). Ten trials of stranger-matched play followed by ten more trials of stranger-matched play are one block of 20 trials. Ten trials of stranger-matched play as baseline followed by ten more trials of stranger-matched play with punishment are two blocks of ten trials, as the treatment changes. Thus, divisions of trials into blocks only for analysis are not treated as blocks.

label: Number of trials
description: The number of trials (rounds) in each block.

label: One-shot vs repeated
description: Whether participants played the game with the same person only once (this also applies if participants switch partners after each trial) versus played the game repeatedly with the same person.

label: One-shot
description: Participants played the game with the same person only once

label: Repeated
description: Participants played the game repeatedly with the same person

label: Nationality or region
description: Participant's nationality according to ISO-3 Country Code.

label: Integrity
description: Integrity involves honesty, trustworthiness, fidelity in keeping oneâs word and obligations, and incorruptibility, or an unwillingness to violate principles regardless of the temptations, costs, and preferences of others (Schlenker, 2008, p. 1081)

label: Religiosity
description: Correlation between any individual difference construct pertaining to the religious sphere (e.g., beliefs in god, church attendance, religious affiliation) and cooperation.

label: Social capital
description: Correlation between cooperation and individual differences in social capital measures, which capture the quality of the networks individuals are immersed in (e.g.,  volunteering, active participation in electoral process, number of friends). Although trust is defined as part of the social capital, it is currently coded separately as an individual difference (trust propensity) or state trust.

label: Identification
description: Correlation between extent to which the participants identify with their partner(s) and cooperation.

label: Matching
description: How participants are paired with others during interactions.

label: Stranger
description: Participants interact with one person for one trial (i.e., one-shot), or switch partners after each trial across many trials (i.e., one-shot repeated)

label: Partner
description: Participants interact with the same partner for multiple trials

label: Trial of cooperation
description: Trial on which cooperation is assessed.

label: Minimum contribution
description: Mandatory minimum contributions or taxation set that minimum contribution players must make. Taxation is institutional, i.e., the threshold is set by an institution (this is different from pledges of contributions, which are coded as âCommunicationâ).

label: Mandatory Minimum
description: Minimum contribution is automatically contributed to the public good

label: Minimum contribution value
description: The value of the minimum contribution to the public good as a proportion of the endowment.

label: z
description: Z statistic

label: Institutional choice
description: Whether participants can choose an institution (such as punishment, reward).

label: Exogenous
description: With exogenous institutions, the structure of the game is given and cannot be changed by players

label: Institutional choice mechanism
description: Endogenous institutions can be established by the participants themselves, such as with a vote or migrating to groups with different institutions.

label: Vote
description: Participants can establish different institutions by vote, requiring some threshold (simple majority, consensus, etc.)

label: Endogenous
description: With endogenous institutions, participants can influence the type of institution provided

label: Institution type
description: The type of institution that can be established.

label: Punishment
description: Punishment is the imposition of negative payoffs on a specific participant after a trial in the game

label: Vote target
description: Whether the vote is to establish a new institution or to remove an existing institution.

label: Establish
description: Vote to establish a new institution

label: Vote outcome
description: Whether the vote resulted in the targeted outcome or did not result in the targeted outcome.

label: Yes Vote
description: The proposal reached the threshold (the institution was established, removed, altered, etc.)

label: No Vote
description: The proposal did not reach the threshold (the institution was not established, removed, altered, etc.)

label: Exogenous
description: Players are matched based on some (non-random) characteristic (e.g., personality, prior play)

label: Partner perception
description: How participants perceive partner(s) in the game according to several characteristics (usually, self-reported).

label: Attractive
description: Partner is perceived to be physically attractive

label: Partner perception level
description: To what extent the partner is perceived in reference to the quality indicated in Partner Perception.

label: high
description: The partner is perceived as high in reference to a specific quality (this may be manipulated or measured in the study)

label: low
description: The partner is perceived as low in reference to a specific quality (this may be manipulated or measured in the study)

label: Unattractive
description: Partner is perceived to be physically unattractive

label: Choice
description: Individual participants can choose to impose an institution on themselves or others.

label: Promise
description: Promises (e.g., of own cooperation or reward)

label: Ongoing
description: Participants could communicate before multiple (all, or at least several) trials (If the game was one-shot, then communication was coded as ongoing)

label: Peer
description: Other participants of the same role

label: Monetary
description: An amount of money often converted from game points

label: Reward
description: Reward is the imposition of positive payoffs on a specific participant after a trial in the game

label: Prosocial/Trustworthy
description: Partner is perceived to be prosocial/trustworthy

label: Synchrony
description: Participants engage in a synchronous activity prior to making decisions in the game. TRUE = Participants engage in a synchronous activity prior to making decisions in the game, FALSE = Participants did not engage in a synchronous activity prior to making decisions in the game.

label: Access to the resource
description: Maximum amount of resource that participants can harvest from the common pool

label: Online
description: The experiment was conducted online on a web platform (e.g., MTurk)

label: Reflective thinking style
description: Reliance on and enjoyment of thinking in an analytical, logical manner [and] a high level of ability to think logically and analytically (Pacini & Epstein, 1999, p. 974).

label: Entitativity
description: Correlation between cooperation and self-reported perception that the group is an entity (e.g., similarity and interdependence)(Gaertner & Schopler, 1998).

label: Entitativity level
description: The relative level of entitativity (i.e., the perception that the group is an entity) between participants.

label: Low
description: Participants were classified as having low levels of entitativity

label: High
description: Participants were classified as having high levels of entitativity

label: Intergroup Prisoner's Dilemma
description: âThe individualsâ payoff for defecting or withholding contribution is higher than his or her payoff for contribution, regardless of what all others (ingroup and outgroup) players do. Withholding contribution, in other words, is the dominant individual strategy. The payoff for i when all in-group members contribute is higher than iâs payoff when none contributes, regardless of the number of out-group contributors. Thus, the dominant group strategy is for all group members to contribute. Player iâs payoff when all players in both groups contribute is lower than his or her payoff when none contributes. This means that the collectively (i.e., Pareto) optimal outcome, the one that maximizes the collective payoff to all players in both groups, is for all of them to withhold contributionâ (Goren & Bornstein, 2000, p. 701).

label: Session
description: Data were analyzed at the session level, so that cooperation displayed in each experimental session is used as observation in the analysis

label: State trust
description: Correlation between cooperation and the extent to which participants report to trust the partner(s) in the game (expectations about others' behavior and a generalized propensity to trust are coded separately).

label: Group size
description: Overall number of people affected by the outcome of the game

label: Perceived criticality
description: Correlation between cooperation and subjective estimates that one's contribution is critical to providing the public good (referred to as "self-efficacy" in some studies).

label: Medium
description: Medium relative level of the ratio of benefits to costs for a member to contribute one monetary unit to the group account

label: W-X
description: Wald Chi-square statistic

label: Achievement
description: Recurrent concern with a standard of excellence and the disposition to derive satisfaction from the mastery of challenging tasks (SchÃ¶nbrodt & Gerstenberg, 2012, p. 726)

label: Avoidance
description: Sensitivity to the presence or absence of negative outcomes [and] vigilant avoidance of losses or failures (Lockwood, Jordan, & Kunda, 2002, p. 854)

label: Gender of the partner
description: Partner's gender as reported in the paper. Positive correlations effect size always mean that participants cooperated more with men than with women.

label: M
description: Male

label: F
description: Female

label: Gender role
description: Gender role refers to the culturally and socially constructed meanings that describe how women and men should behave in certain situations according to feminine and masculine roles learned throughout life (Alabas et al., 2012).

label: career oriented
description: high scoring individuals give a greater importance to the career as compared to more traditional activities (e.g., the care of the family)

label: tradition oriented
description: high scoring individuals on this dimension give a greater importance to more traditional activities (e.g., the care of the family) as compared to the career

label: Pavlov
description: The partner cooperates with probability 0.5 in the first move, then cooperates if and only if both players opted for the same choice in the previous trial

label: Values (Schwartz)
description: Human values according to Schwartz classification.

label: Achievement
description: Defining goal: personal success through demonstrating competence according to social standards (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Tradition
description: Defining goal: respect, commitment, and acceptance of the customs and ideas that oneâs culture or religion provides (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Universalism
description: Defining goal: understanding, appreciation, tolerance, and protection for the welfare of all people and for nature (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Benevolence
description: Defining goal: preserving and enhancing the welfare of those with whom one is in frequent personal contact (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Conformity
description: Defining goal: restraint of actions, inclinations, and impulses likely to upset or harm others and violate social expectations or norms (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Hedonism
description: Defining goal: pleasure or sensuous gratification for oneself (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Power
description: Defining goal: social status and prestige, control or dominance over people and resources (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Security
description: Defining goal: safety, harmony, and stability of society, of relationships, and of self (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Self-direction
description: Defining goal: independent thought and actionâchoosing, creating, exploring (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Stimulation
description: Defining goal: excitement, novelty, and challenge in life (Schwartz, 2012)

label: Political ideology
description: Correlation between cooperation and self-reported political orientation. Lower scores represent left-wing/liberal/democratic ideologies, while higher scores represent right-wing/conservative/republican ideology.

label: Social dominance orientation
description: Individual differences in the preference for group based hierarchy and inequality (Ho et al., 2015, p. 1003)

label: Machiavellianism
description: A duplicitous interpersonal style, characterized by a cynical disregard for morality and a focus on self-interest and personal gain (Muris et al., 2017, p. 184)

label: Focal participant has punished
description: Whether the focal participant punished another player in the previous round. TRUE = Focal participant punished another player in the previous round, FALSE = Focal participant did not punish another player in the previous round.

label: Behavior in different game
description: Correlation between behavior in the current game (i.e., The game coded under "game type" in study characteristics) and behavior in other games.

label: Trust Game - sender
description: In the standard trust game, players are provided an endowment, paired, and assigned to either the role of sender or receiver. At stage one of the game, the sender may either pass nothing, or any portion of the endowment to the receiver. The sender then keeps the remaining endowment for themselves. The experimenter then triples the amount sent to the receiver. In stage two, the receiver may either pass nothing, or pass any portion of the money received back to the sender

label: Trust Game - receiver
description: In the standard trust game, players are provided an endowment, paired, and assigned to either the role of sender or receiver. At stage one of the game, the sender may either pass nothing, or any portion of the endowment to the receiver. The sender then keeps the remaining endowment for themselves. The experimenter then triples the amount sent to the receiver. In stage two, the receiver may either pass nothing, or pass any portion of the money received back to the sender.

label: Self-esteem
description: Individual differences in the evaluation of oneâs self-worth and self-respect (Gnambs, Scharl, & Schroeders, 2018, p. 14)

label: Sequential turn-taking
description: Each player makes a punishment decision in turn

label: Sequential turn-taking
description: Each participant makes a reward decision in turn

label: Forgiveness
description: Disposition to forgive interpersonal transgressions over time and across situations (Berry, Worthington, OâConnor, Parrott, & Wade, 2005, p. 183)

label: Risk-taking (behavioral measure)
description: Risk-taking preferences are measured by participants  making a choice between options that involve probabilisic outcomes.

label: rho
description: Spearman's rank correlation coefficient

label: Loss
description: Negative payoff that resulted in a loss of resources due to endogenous (e.g., not reaching a threshold) or exogenous  (e.g., shocks) factors

label: Intuitive thinking style
description: Reliance on and enjoyment of feelings and intuitions in making decisions [and] a high level of ability with respect to oneâs intuitive impressions and feelings (Pacini & Epstein, 1999, p. 974)

label: Irrelevant
description: Messages irrelevant to the game

label: Empathy
description: âOtherâcenteredâ emotion, which can result from observing another individual in need and imagining the person's situation (Batson, 1991)

label: Concern for others
description: Individual differences in the extent to which [â¦] other peopleâs interests serve as guides for behavior (Gerbasi & Prentice, 2013, p. 495)

label: cooperative
description: Participants were provided with the information that their partner behaved cooperatively

label: noncooperative
description: Participants were provided with the information that their partner behaved noncooperatively

label: Anxiety
description: The stable tendency to attend to, experience, and report negative emotions such as fears, worries, and anxiety across many situations (Gidron, 2013, p. 1989)

label: Endogenous
description: Players choose with whom to interact

label: Incentive structure
description: Information about how payoffs in the game are determined. Stochastic vs deterministic payoff structures are included in this category

label: Continuous Public Goods Game
description: In the continuous public goods game, subjects are provided an endowment and decide any portion to allocate to the public good, and the remaining about is kept for themselves. The group contributions in the public pool are multiplied by a factor (greater than one and less than the number of players, N) and it is divided among players, regardless of the players contributions

label: Dictator Game
description: In standard dictator game, participants are assigned to either the role of dictator or recipient. The dictator is given a fixed amount of money and is entitled to decide how much money to keep and how much money to give to the recipient

label: Psychopathy
description: A personality trait characterized by enduring antisocial behavior, diminished empathy and remorse, and disinhibited or bold behavior (Muris et al., 2017, p. 184)

label: Narcissism
description: A grandiose view of the self, a strong sense of entitlement and superiority, a lack of empathy, and a need for social admiration, as well as tendencies to show dominant, charming, bragging, impulsive, and aggressive behaviors (Back et al., 2013, p. 1014)

label: Ethnicity (US)
description: Participant's ethnic group (values adopted from US Census).

label: Black or African American
description: Africa

label: White
description: Europe, Middle East, North Africa

label: Heterogeneous ethnicity
description: Whether groups had a mixed ethnic composition (also applies to mixed nationalities and small-scale societies). TRUE = Groups had a mixed ethnic composition (also applies to mixed nationalities and small-scale societies), FALSE = Groups had a homogeneous ethnic composition (also applies to nationalities and small-scale societies).

label: Social desirability
description: Tendency to provide answers that are considered socially acceptable in order to present themselves in a favorable light

label: acquaintance
description: Their partner is an acquaintance

label: Emotional intelligence
description: Extent to which [individuals] attend to, process, and utilize affect-laden information of an intrapersonal (e.g., managing oneâs own emotions) or interpersonal (e.g., managing othersâ emotions) nature (Petrides & Furnham, 2006, p. 553)

label: Prisoner's Dilemma Game
description: In the standard prisoner's dilemma game, the relative value of the four outcomes reflects the following relationships: DC > CC > DD > CD

label: g index
description: Index that identifies the strength of the underlying structural impetus toward cooperation or competition in repeated, multitrial PD tasks with probabilistic endpoints. Their expected gain index, g = (1/(1 - p)][R - T + p(T -P)], where p is the probability that play will continue (Bettenhausen & Murnighan, 1991)

label: Group variability
description: Participants are given information about the variability in group member behavior.

label: Low
description: Participants are told there is relatively low amounts of variability in group member behavior

label: High
description: Participants are told there is relatively high amounts of variability in group member behavior

label: Payoff matrix
description: The matrix that represents the possible behaviors and outcomes for the participants

label: Other
description: Other strategies

label: Control
description: The participant has equal control over resources relative to another person.

label: Ultimatum game - Proposer
description: In standard ultimatum game, the first player proposes how to divide a sum of money with the second party. If the second player rejects this division, neither gets anything. If the second player accepts, the first gets her demand and the second gets the rest

label: Ultimatum game - Responder
description: In standard ultimatum game, the first player proposes how to divide a sum of money with the second party. If the second player rejects this division, neither gets anything. If the second player accepts, the first gets her demand and the second gets the rest

label: MPCR
description: The ratio of benefits to costs for a member to contribute one monetary unit to the group account (calculated as multiplier divided by group size)

label: group
description: The decision maker is a group of participants. Each decision maker group makes a single decision, to be then matched with other decisions in the game and produce an outcome for all decision makers involved (e.g., two groups of three participants make two decisions to be matched in a  PDG)

label: E
description: Fisher's exact test

label: Elected
description: Leader is voted and elected by other participants

label: Endogenous
description: Leader is selected by participants in the game

label: Leadership role
description: Participant is assigned to being the Leader or the Follower.

label: Leader
description: Leader behavior in the game

label: Follower
description: Follower behavior in the game

label: Punishment
description: In interdependent situations, if one party can punish or has a better punishment ratio in comparison to others with no/less punishment power, the person with the better ratio, is more powerful (Nieper et al., 2018)

label: Leader
description: A participant with some form of higher, relative social power; see Power

label: Exit option
description: Whether the game provided the option to walk away and not interact in the game. TRUE = Exit option is provided, FALSE = Exit option is not provided

label: Knowledge of experimental games (correlation)
description: Correlation between reported experience with economic games and/or game theory and cooperation.

label: Locus of control
description: The degree to which persons expect that a reinforcement or an outcome of their behavior is contingent on their own behavior or personal characteristics versus the degree to which persons expect that the reinforcement or outcome is a function of chance, luck, or fate, is under the control of powerful others, or is simply unpredictable (Rotter, 1990, p. 489)

label: Real partner
description: Whether participants interact with real or imagined participants in the game.

label: Hypothetical
description: Participants imagined interactions with others or played with a computer

label: Real
description: Participants involved in real-time interactions with real participant(s)

label: Network
description: A peer in a game with network structure

label: Endowment size
description: Information about maximum number of tokens participants were endowed with (or could contribute/harvest)

label: Resource size
description: Overall size of the resource from which participants can make withdrawals in a resource dilemma game

label: Step-level Public Goods Game
description: In the step level public goods game, subjects are provided an endowment and decide any portion of the endowment to allocate to the public good, and the remaining amonut is kept for themselves. The group contributions to the public pool are multiplied by a factor and it is divided among players (regardless of their contributions) only if a certain threshold (provision point) is met

label: Collectivism
description: Oneâs tendency to give priority to the collective self over the private self, especially when these two come into conflict (Yamagishi, Kuhlman, & Sugimori, 1995, p. 659)

label: Competitiveness
description: Individualsâ desire to do better than others, their desire to win in interpersonal situations, and their enjoyment of interpersonal competition (Houston, McIntire, Kinnie, & Terry, 2002, p. 286)

label: Feedback
description: information participants receive after each decision round

label: Marginal rate of substitution
description: Tradeoff between contribution and return from the public good, in order to keep the subjective utility constant

label: MRS
description: Tradeoff between contribution and return from the public good, in order to keep the subjective utility constant.

label: MRS level
description: Relative level of the tradeoff between contribution and return from the public good, in order to keep the subjective utility constant.

label: Low
description: Low relative level of the tradeoff between contribution and return from the public good, in order to keep the subjective utility constant

label: High
description: High relative level of the tradeoff between contribution and return from the public good, in order to keep the subjective utility constant

label: Medium
description: Medium relative level of the tradeoff between contribution and return from the public good, in order to keep the subjective utility constant

label: Migration
description: Participants can choose between groups with different institutions

label: Other
description: Any other institution

label: Private account return
description: Private gain for each token contributed to the Private Account.

label: Private account return level
description: Relative level of the private gain for each token contributed to the Private Account.

label: High
description: High relative level of the private gain for each token contributed to the Private Account

label: Symmetric private account return
description: Whether all participants within a group receive the same or different private gain for each token contributed to the Private Account. TRUE = Symmetric private account return, FALSE = Asymmetric Private account return

label: Low
description: Low relative level of the private gain for each token contributed to the Private Account

label: Degree of friendship
description: Correlation between cooperation and the extent to which the participant and their partner(s) in the game describe themselves as friends.

label: Medium
description: The treatment was classified as having a relative medium level of uncertainty

label: Medium
description: Medium relative size of the resource that participants can withdraw in a resource dilemma game

label: Unconditional cooperator
description: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants who always contributed the full amount to the public good

label: Watching eyes
description: Participants are exposed to cues resembling watching eyes while making their decision in the game. TRUE = Watching eyes present, FALSE = Watching eyes absent.

label: Knowledge of experimental games
description: Whether participants report to have experience with economic games and/or game theory. TRUE = Participants report to have experience with economic games and/or game theory, FALSE = Participants report not to have experience with economic games and/or game theory.

label: Partner's choice
description: Partner choice involves matching of participants based on either the players' or the experimenter's decision. If partner choice is in place, code for partner choice

label: Rebate vs refund
description: Participants are given back (some of) their contributions to the public good, if the public good is not provided (or their partner chooses not to cooperate).

label: Absent
description: No refund/rebate is provided

label: Full Refund
description: Participants are fully refunded any amount to contributed to the public good, often depending on contributions made by others

label: Step return
description: Return for reaching the threshold in step-level Public Goods Game.

label: Step return level
description: Relative level of return for reaching the threshold in step-level Public Goods Game.

label: Low
description: Low relative level of return for reaching the threshold in step-level Public Goods Game

label: High
description: High relative level of return for reaching the threshold in step-level Public Goods Game

label: Medium
description: Medium relative level of return for reaching the threshold in step-level Public Goods Game

label: Interaction
description: Interaction effect

description: In a game with leadership by example, there is a single privileged player that makes a punishment decision before all others

label: Volunteer
description: Participants volunteer to be the leader

label: b/c ratio
description: Ratio between the cost c paid by a cooperator, and the correspondent benefit b received by the partner

label: Other Game
description: None of the game type categories apply

label: Other
description: Other agent types not included in the current categories

label: Participant's own behavior (correlation)
description: Correlation between participant's behavior at two different time points (e.g., current trials and past trials).

label: Partitioned resource
description: Whether participants are provided with a partitioned resource (e.g., the resource is already divided by the number of participants, which makes easier to withdraw an equal share). TRUE = The resource is presented as partitioned, FALSE = the resource was not partitioned.

label: Unknown
description: Neither the participant or their partner know each others' group membership

label: Minimum contribution level
description: The relative level of the minimum contribution to the public good as a proportion of the endowment.

label: Low
description: Low relative level of the minimum contribution to the public good as a proportion of the endowment

label: Medium
description: Medium relative level of the minimum contribution to the public good as a proportion of the endowment

label: High
description: High relative level of the minimum contribution to the public good as a proportion of the endowment

description: Participants have adopted a specific goal when interacting in the game (both as result of self report measures and classified as such based on behavior in other tasks). label: Non-monetary Material

label: Reward effectiveness
description: The ratio of the cost of reward for the participant who decides to reward, to the benefit of reward for the participant who receives the reward (e.g., if the reward costs 1 point to deliver and benefits the recipient by 3 points, = .33).

label: Criticality level
description: Different objective or subjective understanding that the participant's decision is more or less critical in providing the public good.

label: High
description: Participants have relatively high amounts of criticalilty in providing the public good

label: Low
description: Participants have relatively low amounts of criticality in providing the public good

label: Hormones administration
description: Participants were administered hormones prior to the decision in the game (e.g., via intranasal administration).

label: Oxytocin
description: Oxytocin hormone

label: Vasopressin
description: Vasopressin hormone

label: Placebo
description: Participants were administered a placebo

label: Familiar
description: Partner is perceived to be familiar

label: Other values
description: Values are abstract cognitive structures that indicate desirable ways of behaving in a broad range of situations (Rokeach, 1973; Schwartz, 1992).

label: Random
